queries.company_overview:
CoreWeave, Inc. operates a purpose-built AI cloud platform delivering GPU-accelerated compute, storage, networking, and managed services for AI training, inference, VFX/rendering, and other high-performance workloads.

Main business units / segments:
- GPU Compute
- CPU Compute
- Storage Services (AI Object Storage)
- Networking Services
- Managed Services (Kubernetes, Observability)

High-level financials: FY2024 revenue $1.9B; FY2024 net loss $863M; Market capitalization $51.84B (as of 2025-11-10), all USD.

Competitive positioning: CoreWeave competes with hyperscalers Amazon Web Services, Microsoft Azure, Google Cloud, Oracle, and IBM, plus specialized GPU cloud providers such as Lambda and Crusoe. It differentiates by being AI-focused with performance-optimized clusters and rapid adoption of NVIDIA’s latest GPUs (e.g., Blackwell); while smaller than hyperscalers, it claims workload-specific performance advantages and has partnered with some competitors.

Recent major news:
- 2025-03-31 Completed IPO at $40 per share; began trading on Nasdaq as CRWV.
- 2025-05-05 Completed acquisition of Weights & Biases.
- 2025-05-14 Reported Q1 2025 revenue $981.6M; announced multi-year OpenAI deal adding $11.2B to backlog; IBM Granite partnership.
- 2025-07-07 Announced definitive agreement to acquire Core Scientific in an all-stock transaction.
- 2025-08-12 Reported Q2 2025 revenue $1.21B; highlighted first-to-scale NVIDIA Blackwell portfolio availability.

What is CoreWeave's total interest expen.query: What is CoreWeave's total interest expense run-rate and interest coverage ratio in 2025?
What is CoreWeave's total interest expen.answer: CoreWeave’s reported net interest expense in 2025 ran at roughly $264–267 million per quarter in the first half, implying an annualized interest expense run-rate of about $1.1 billion. Its interest coverage ratio in 2025 is around 0.3x on a trailing-12-month basis, indicating minimal coverage (and effectively 0x in Q1 given negative operating income).

What is the expected closing timeline an.query: What is the expected closing timeline and integration plan for CoreWeave's Core Scientific acquisition?
What is the expected closing timeline an.answer: The transaction is expected to close in Q4 2025, subject to regulatory approvals and a vote by Core Scientific shareholders. Integration will verticalize CoreWeave’s data center footprint by bringing Core Scientific’s ~1.3 GW power capacity in-house, eliminating over $10B of future lease obligations, targeting about $500M in annual run-rate savings by 2027, and repurposing crypto mining capacity toward AI/HPC workloads (with the option to divest).

search_results.title: CoreWeave to Acquire Core Scientific
search_results.snippet: CoreWeave and Core Scientific signed a definitive all-stock agreement with closing expected in Q4 2025, pending regulatory and shareholder approvals. The integration plan is to “verticalize” CoreWeave’s data center ownership by absorbing ~1.3 GW of power capacity, eliminate over $10B in future lease overhead, achieve roughly $500M in annual run-rate savings by 2027, and repurpose crypto mining capacity toward AI/HPC or divest it.

search_results.title: AI cloud firm CoreWeave to acquire Core Scientific for $9bn
search_results.snippet: Reports an all-stock merger slated to close in Q4 2025. Integration brings ~1.3GW under CoreWeave (≈840MW for HPC, ≈500MW crypto), removes about $10B in lease costs over 12 years, and targets ~$500M annual savings by 2027, with plans to reallocate or divest crypto operations as part of the AI/HPC focus.

search_results.title: CoreWeave $9 billion acquisition of Core Scientific

Notes the combined footprint will include ~1.3GW of gross power with 1GW+ of expansion potential, supporting CoreWeave’s vertical integration strategy.

What are the termination rights and mini.query: What are the termination rights and minimum commitments in CoreWeave's OpenAI contract?
What are the termination rights and mini.answer: The Master Services Agreement allows either party to terminate the MSA and any order for cause after notice and cure, and requires a defined transition period during which services continue and only services actually provided are paid; if termination is for Customer nonpayment, CoreWeave may later transfer/sell reserved servers and offset proceeds. Minimum commitments are structured via multi‑year, take‑or‑pay reserved‑capacity order forms: CoreWeave’s IPO prospectus describes such take‑or‑pay commitments and cites up to $11.55B of expected revenue tied to the OpenAI MSA, while a later 8‑K discloses a September 2025 order under which OpenAI committed to pay up to about $6.5B through May 2031, subject to delivery and service availability.

search_results.title: EX-10.24 - Master Services Agreement (CoreWeave and OpenAI) - SEC.gov
search_results.snippet: The MSA’s Term and Termination section permits either party to terminate for cause after a cure period and provides for a Termination Period during which services continue and only services actually performed are payable. It also specifies transition services, payment terms during the Termination Period, and that if CoreWeave terminates for nonpayment, it must continue services during the Termination Period and may subsequently transfer or sell reserved servers with proceeds credited against amounts owed.

search_results.title: 8-K: Entry into a Material Definitive Agreement (OpenAI Order Form) - SEC.gov
search_results.snippet: On Sept. 23, 2025, CoreWeave and OpenAI executed a new order under the existing MSA. Subject to termination provisions and delivery/availability requirements, OpenAI committed to pay CoreWeave up to approximately $6.5 billion through May 31, 2031 under the order; the filing confirms the MSA remains in effect until orders expire or are terminated and that either party may terminate the MSA (and any order) for cause.

search_results.title: 424B4 - CoreWeave, Inc. Prospectus - SEC.gov
search_results.snippet: CoreWeave states that the vast majority of revenue comes from multi‑year committed contracts sold on a take‑or‑pay basis and discloses $15.1B of remaining performance obligations as of year‑end 2024. The prospectus highlights up to $11.55B of future revenue associated with a recently signed MSA with OpenAI, evidencing the scale and take‑or‑pay nature of the minimum commitments.

Management announced the increase on the Q2 earnings call and in the accompanying outlook materials on August 12, 2025, citing continued strong customer demand.

How is CoreWeave mitigating Microsoft cu.query: How is CoreWeave mitigating Microsoft customer concentration risk highlighted in the S-1?
How is CoreWeave mitigating Microsoft cu.answer: CoreWeave is reducing its reliance on Microsoft by converting more revenue into multi‑year, take‑or‑pay commitments with other mega‑customers and by signing a direct, multi‑year Master Services Agreement with OpenAI. In its amended S‑1, it says Microsoft is expected to represent less than half of future committed contract revenue when combining its $15.1B RPO with the new OpenAI deal (valued up to ~$11.9B), broadening its customer mix and adding multi‑year revenue visibility.

search_results.title: S-1/A
search_results.snippet: The amended S‑1 discloses Microsoft was CoreWeave’s largest customer in 2023–2024, but states Microsoft is expected to account for under half of future committed contract revenue when combining $15.1B in remaining performance obligations (as of Dec. 31, 2024) with up to $11.55B from a newly signed OpenAI Master Services Agreement. It emphasizes revenue is largely multi‑year, take‑or‑pay, with top customers expanding commitments over time.

search_results.title: CoreWeave inks $11.9 billion contract with OpenAI ahead of IPO
search_results.snippet: Reuters reports CoreWeave signed a five‑year, $11.9B AI infrastructure deal with OpenAI, including a $350M OpenAI equity stake at IPO. The article notes roughly two‑thirds of CoreWeave’s 2024 revenue came from Microsoft and frames the OpenAI contract as a major boost ahead of the IPO that diversifies customer exposure beyond Microsoft.

search_results.title: CoreWeave’s Agreement with OpenAI to Deliver AI Infrastructure
search_results.snippet: CoreWeave announced a dedicated compute agreement with OpenAI valued up to $11.9B, with OpenAI also investing $350M in CoreWeave. OpenAI called CoreWeave an “important addition” to its infrastructure portfolio alongside Microsoft and Oracle—making this direct, multi‑year contract a clear step that broadens CoreWeave’s revenue base beyond Microsoft.

What contracted power purchase agreement.query: What contracted power purchase agreements back CoreWeave's data center operations by region?
What contracted power purchase agreement.answer: Public disclosures show CoreWeave has a large-scale power purchase agreement in Spain, primarily sourcing solar and wind, to back its Southern Europe region centered around Barcelona. The company says it only uses PPAs where needed and has not publicly detailed PPAs for other regions (e.g., UK, Nordics, US); its European expansion notes 100% renewable supply via local grids/partners rather than named PPAs.

search_results.title: CoreWeave has "large scale" solar and wind PPA in Spain
search_results.snippet: CoreWeave’s international GM said the company signed a “large-scale” PPA in Spain, with most power from solar and wind, and that it uses PPAs only where needed. He added a new Spain data center is due within ~90 days with a 100MW solar farm adjacent. DCD notes CoreWeave has not otherwise publicized its PPAs or renewable strategy; the Barcelona site will serve as its Southern Europe region.

search_results.title: The Mayor of Barcelona Jaume Collboni Inaugurates Data Center Hosting CoreWeave's Leading AI Cloud Platform, in Partnership with MERLIN Edged
search_results.snippet: CoreWeave’s 15MW Barcelona deployment anchors its Southern Europe region, with plans to expand to Blackwell in 2026. The announcement emphasizes operation on 100% renewable energy and abundant regional renewables, highlighting Iberia’s role in backing CoreWeave’s southern European capacity (though no additional PPA beyond Spain is named).

search_results.title: CoreWeave's European Expansion: Let’s Power Tomorrow's AI Innovations
search_results.snippet: CoreWeave says three new data centers in Norway, Sweden, and Spain will be powered by 100% renewable energy, alongside earlier UK expansion. While it confirms renewable-backed operations across Europe, only Spain is publicly identified with a contracted PPA; elsewhere the company has not disclosed specific PPA deals.

What guaranteed 2025-2026 Nvidia GPU all.query: What guaranteed 2025-2026 Nvidia GPU allocation volumes has CoreWeave secured under contracts?
What guaranteed 2025-2026 Nvidia GPU all.answer: There is no public disclosure of any specific, guaranteed 2025–2026 Nvidia GPU allocation volumes for CoreWeave. CoreWeave’s S-1/A discusses early/priority access to Nvidia GPUs and notes operating 250,000 GPUs as of Dec. 31, 2024, but does not list contracted unit allocations for 2025–2026. The only ‘guarantee’ disclosed is Nvidia’s $6.3B backstop to purchase CoreWeave’s unsold cloud capacity through April 13, 2032, which is not a GPU supply allocation and does not specify volumes.

search_results.title: S-1/A

search_results.title: Nvidia commits $6.3B for CoreWeave’s unused cloud capacity
search_results.snippet: An SEC-filed deal obligates Nvidia to buy CoreWeave’s residual unsold capacity through April 13, 2032; the article notes the volume of compute is undisclosed. This is a revenue backstop, not a 2025–2026 GPU supply allocation with specified unit volumes.

search_results.title: NVIDIA Blackwell Now Generally Available in the Cloud
search_results.snippet: Nvidia says CoreWeave is the first cloud to make GB200 NVL72 instances generally available and can scale to up to 110,000 GPUs, speaking to capability and scale. It does not state any contracted or guaranteed 2025–2026 Nvidia GPU allocation volumes.

What portion of CoreWeave 2025 revenue i.query: What portion of CoreWeave 2025 revenue is contractually committed versus usage-based?
What portion of CoreWeave 2025 revenue i.answer: CoreWeave has not disclosed an exact 2025 split. Management says the vast majority of revenue is from multi‑year, take‑or‑pay committed contracts, with only a small on‑demand/usage component. In its S‑1, 96% of 2024 revenue came from committed contracts; Q1’25 materials and the $25.9B revenue backlog underpin FY25 guidance, indicating 2025 revenue remains overwhelmingly contractually committed.

search_results.title: CoreWeave Q1’25 Earnings Call Transcript (PDF)
search_results.snippet: On the Q1 2025 call, CFO Nitin Agrawal said “the vast majority of our revenue comes from long‑term committed contracts,” and framed FY25 guidance ($4.9–$5.1B) as supported by a $25.9B revenue backlog (RPO plus other committed amounts) — underscoring that only a small share is usage/on‑demand.

search_results.title: CoreWeave Q1’25 Earnings Presentation (PDF)
search_results.snippet: The investor slides emphasize that long‑term, committed contracts provide strong revenue visibility and show a $25.9B revenue backlog as of Q1’25, indicating that FY2025 revenue is largely under contract with a minor usage‑based component.

search_results.title: Seven Things To Know About CoreWeave’s S‑1: Top Customers, Revenue and More
search_results.snippet: CoreWeave’s S‑1 states that committed, take‑or‑pay contracts accounted for 96% of 2024 revenue (up from 88% in 2023), signaling a minimal on‑demand share and that the 2025 mix remains heavily contract‑based.

What are CoreWeave's plans to support GB.query: What are CoreWeave's plans to support GB300 Blackwell Ultra configurations at scale?
What are CoreWeave's plans to support GB.answer: CoreWeave is rolling out Dell‑integrated NVIDIA GB300 NVL72 racks and plans to scale deployments globally, bringing GB300 servers online through 2025. The platform is tied into CoreWeave’s production AI stack—CKS and Slurm on Kubernetes, rack‑scale observability with RLCC, and Weights & Biases integrations—and runs over NVLink and Quantum‑X800 InfiniBand in liquid‑cooled facilities (with Switch/Vertiv), enabling rack‑ and cluster‑scale GB300 Blackwell Ultra configurations for large‑scale training, reasoning, and inference.

search_results.title: CoreWeave Becomes First Hyperscaler to Deploy NVIDIA GB300 NVL72 Platform
search_results.snippet: CoreWeave announced it is the first AI cloud to deploy NVIDIA GB300 NVL72 systems for customers and will expand deployments globally at significant scale. The Blackwell Ultra racks are being brought online with Dell, Switch, and Vertiv and integrated into CoreWeave’s stack (CKS, Slurm on Kubernetes, RLCC, and new observability via Weights & Biases) to support frontier workloads at scale.

search_results.title: Dell ships first Nvidia GB300 NVL72 to CoreWeave
search_results.snippet: Dell delivered the first GB300 NVL72 rack to CoreWeave, which plans to bring its GB300 servers online throughout 2025, with the initial rack fully assembled, tested, and deployed in the US. Each liquid‑cooled cabinet links 72 Blackwell Ultra GPUs with Grace CPUs, targeting higher performance than GB200 to scale training, reasoning, and inference services.

search_results.title: CoreWeave Implements NVIDIA GB300 NVL72 in Cloud
search_results.snippet: CoreWeave deployed the first production GB300 NVL72—72 Blackwell Ultra GPUs interconnected via NVLink and Quantum‑X800 InfiniBand—and optimized it with its Kubernetes‑based stack (CKS and Slurm on K8s), rack‑scale observability, and W&B integrations. Designed for multi‑trillion‑parameter workloads with 21TB of HBM3e per rack and 800Gbps per‑GPU networking, this setup underscores plans to run GB300 configurations at scale.

How sensitive is CoreWeave revenue to el.query: How sensitive is CoreWeave revenue to electricity price changes under customer contracts?
How sensitive is CoreWeave revenue to el.answer: CoreWeave’s revenue is minimally sensitive to electricity price swings because most of its top line comes from multi‑year, take‑or‑pay customer contracts with fixed pricing per GPU-hour over the term. While on‑demand fees can change, committed revenue is set by contract; power price volatility primarily impacts cost of revenue and margins rather than the contractual rates billed to customers.

search_results.title: S-1 - SEC.gov
search_results.snippet: CoreWeave states that the vast majority of revenue comes from multi-year committed contracts, where customers purchase access to its platform on a take‑or‑pay basis, with a smaller portion sold on-demand. This indicates revenue is largely governed by fixed, contract terms rather than indexed to electricity prices; power costs mainly affect cost of revenue and margins.

search_results.title: CoreWeave IPO: S1 Breakdown - Mostly metrics
search_results.snippet: The S‑1 breakdown highlights that 96% of CoreWeave’s revenue comes from multi‑year, locked‑in ‘take‑or‑pay’ contracts—customers pay whether they use the compute or not. That structure implies top-line is driven by contracted rates, not variable inputs like electricity; energy price swings more directly impact gross margin.

search_results.title: CoreWeave (Deep dive) - Outperforming the Market
search_results.snippet: This S‑1 deep dive notes that committed customer contracts generally have fixed pricing for the contract duration, measured in dollars per contracted GPU‑hour and billed monthly. Fixed‑rate terms indicate revenue is not directly repriced with electricity costs, so power price volatility mostly affects costs rather than contracted revenue.

How much CoreWeave revenue is expected f.query: How much CoreWeave revenue is expected from OpenAI contract during FY2025?

Management’s FY2025 total revenue guidance is $5.15–$5.35 billion, but customer-level contributions were not broken out on the Q2’25 call.

How does CoreWeave's TCO compare to AWS.query: How does CoreWeave's TCO compare to AWS for H100 clusters at scale?
How does CoreWeave's TCO compare to AWS.answer: At scale, CoreWeave positions itself as lower-TCO for H100 training by delivering higher effective utilization (MFU/goodput), so the same job can consume fewer GPU-hours than on generic clouds. Independent reporting notes CoreWeave’s stack can lift training efficiency by ~20% versus hyperscalers, which reduces total time and spend. However, AWS cut H100 (P5) prices by up to 44% in mid-2025, bringing on-demand rates down and narrowing or reversing pure $/GPU-hr differences; today, per-GPU-hour AWS can be cheaper in many regions, while job-completion TCO can still favor CoreWeave if its efficiency gains and negotiated rates apply.

search_results.title: CoreWeave’s 250,000-Strong GPU Fleet Undercuts The Big Clouds
search_results.snippet: Independent analysis of CoreWeave’s S‑1 reports its AI-first stack (SUNK, Tensorizer, InfiniBand) can push training efficiency to roughly 55–65% MFU versus the 35–45% often seen on generic clouds, so the same workload needs fewer GPU-hours. The piece also observes big clouds can charge up to about 2× CoreWeave’s H100 hour at list in some cases, meaning jobs can complete faster and at lower total cost when measured by job completion rather than sticker $/GPU-hr.

This materially lowers AWS’s per-GPU-hour pricing for H100 clusters and narrows TCO gaps versus specialized GPU clouds.

search_results.snippet: By late 2025, third‑party tracking shows AWS H100 on-demand around $3.9–$4.2 per GPU-hour after mid‑’25 cuts, while CoreWeave’s public H100 list is about $6.16/GPU‑hr; specialized providers often undercut $3 and AWS Savings Plans/spot can lower rates further. Pure $/GPU‑hr can now favor AWS, but effective TCO still depends on utilization and negotiated enterprise pricing.

What is CoreWeave's roadmap for Tensoriz.query: What is CoreWeave's roadmap for Tensorizer improvements and benchmarked loading performance gains?
What is CoreWeave's roadmap for Tensoriz.answer: CoreWeave’s stated roadmap for Tensorizer includes adding support for non-slice shared tensors (to preserve weight tying), which is on the backlog and slated for implementation. Benchmarks show significant loading and latency gains: on GPT‑J‑6B, Tensorizer loads fastest (median ~8.22s vs ~10.87s SafeTensors and ~15.02s Hugging Face), and on OPT‑30B with A100, it achieves ~23.23s median vs ~36.75s/~35.18s. In scale‑from‑zero tests, average request latency was over 5× faster than Hugging Face with fewer pod spin‑ups and lower RAM use. Tensorizer also reaches wire‑speed loading (~5 GB/s on 40GbE), making performance effectively network‑bound.

search_results.title: Decrease PyTorch Model Load Times with CoreWeave’s Tensorizer
search_results.snippet: CoreWeave’s blog details Tensorizer’s design and reproducible benchmarks: GPT‑J‑6B loads fastest with Tensorizer (median 8.22s vs 10.87s SafeTensors and 15.02s Hugging Face) and OPT‑30B on A100 shows an even larger gap (median 23.23s vs 36.75s and 35.18s). In a real‑world scale‑from‑zero test, average request latency was >5× faster vs Hugging Face, with fewer pod spin‑ups and lower RAM. The roadmap notes support for non‑slice shared tensors is in the backlog and will be implemented soon.

search_results.title: Tensorizer | CoreWeave
search_results.snippet: CoreWeave’s docs explain Tensorizer’s zero‑copy streaming from HTTP/S3 and include benchmark figures: on OPT‑30B with A100, Tensorizer achieves 23.23s median (22.8s avg) vs 36.75s (39.3s) for SafeTensors and 35.18s (32.1s) for Hugging Face. A real‑world benchmark shows >5× faster average latency when scaling from zero due to faster model loading and lazy loading, alongside lower resource usage.

search_results.title: GitHub - coreweave/tensorizer: Module, Model, and Tensor Serialization/Deserialization
search_results.snippet: The repository documents Tensorizer’s capabilities and speed profile: extremely fast loads directly from HTTP/HTTPS and S3, with deserialization primarily network‑bound. It reports GPT‑J (20GB) loading at wire speed (~5 GB/s) on a 40GbE network, illustrating the ceiling on loading performance that underlies the observed startup and latency gains.

How do U.S. export controls on GPUs impa.query: How do U.S. export controls on GPUs impact CoreWeave cross-border deployments and sales?
How do U.S. export controls on GPUs impa.answer: U.S. export controls now impose a worldwide licensing regime on advanced GPUs (ECCN 3A090/4A090) and create a three-tier system that blocks exports to China/Macau and other D:5 countries, while enabling vetted providers to deploy abroad under Data Center Validated End User authorizations. For CoreWeave, this means European and other Tier‑1 deployments can proceed under authorizations (with reporting and compute-allocation conditions), sales into many Tier‑2 markets may require licenses or be capped, and access or support for restricted end users is a compliance risk—so expansion skews toward allies like the UK/EU and away from D:5 destinations.

search_results.title: Framework for Artificial Intelligence Diffusion (Interim Final Rule) – BIS Federal Register
search_results.snippet: Commerce’s AI Diffusion rule imposes a global license requirement on advanced-computing GPUs (ECCN 3A090/4A090) and updates Data Center Validated End User authorizations to facilitate exports to low‑risk destinations while maintaining strict controls for China/Macau and other D:5 countries. It establishes a three‑tier framework and allows vetted providers to build data centers abroad (outside D:5) under specified conditions, allocations, and reporting—directly shaping how U.S. GPU cloud providers execute cross‑border deployments and sales.

search_results.title: U.S. Department of Commerce Establishes Export Control Framework Limiting the Diffusion of Advanced AI and Expands Advanced Computing Controls – Covington
search_results.snippet: BIS’s January 2025 rules create a worldwide licensing regime for advanced GPUs and certain AI model weights, a three‑tier country system, and new Data Center VEU pathways. A Universal VEU lets Tier‑1‑headquartered companies deploy clusters globally (excluding D:5) subject to geographic compute allocations and notifications, and adds a compliance red flag for IaaS providers—defining where U.S. GPU clouds can export, how much they can install, and the diligence required for cross‑border customers.

search_results.title: GPU cloud firm CoreWeave to launch data centers in mainland Europe – DataCenterDynamics
search_results.snippet: CoreWeave is expanding cross‑border, investing $2.2 billion to open three new European data centers by end‑2025, in addition to a £1 billion UK build‑out. Planned sites in Sweden and Norway (with Spain discussed) confirm active overseas deployments in allied jurisdictions—providing context for how U.S. export controls and authorization regimes will govern the company’s shipments of high‑end GPUs and cross‑border sales.

Is CFIUS review applicable to CoreWeave.query: Is CFIUS review applicable to CoreWeave acquisitions or strategic investments in 2025?
Is CFIUS review applicable to CoreWeave.answer: CFIUS review in 2025 applies to transactions that involve a foreign person investing in or acquiring a U.S. business, including certain non‑controlling investments in TID U.S. businesses (critical technology, critical infrastructure, or sensitive personal data). For a U.S. company like CoreWeave, its own acquisitions or strategic investments are generally not subject to CFIUS unless a foreign person is part of the deal (e.g., a foreign investor taking non‑passive rights or control in CoreWeave or in a U.S. TID target). Mandatory filings can be triggered where a foreign government has a substantial interest or critical‑technology export authorization would be required, while purely passive stakes of 10% or less without special rights are outside CFIUS jurisdiction.

search_results.title: The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS)
search_results.snippet: CFIUS is an interagency committee authorized to review certain transactions involving foreign investment in the United States and certain real estate transactions by foreign persons to assess national security risk; under FIRRMA its authorities extend to some non‑controlling investments, with recent rule updates emphasizing enforcement and mitigation.

search_results.title: Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS)
search_results.snippet: CRS explains that CFIUS jurisdiction covers mergers, acquisitions, and takeovers that could result in foreign control of a U.S. business, certain noncontrolling investments in TID U.S. businesses, and certain real estate; filings are mandatory in select cases (e.g., foreign government substantial interest or critical‑technology export licensing).

search_results.title: Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States — Key Questions Answered (2025)
search_results.snippet: Latham summarizes that CFIUS reviews covered control transactions and certain non‑controlling investments by foreign persons; purely passive investments of 10% or less are outside jurisdiction, greenfield deals are generally beyond reach, and mandatory filings can be triggered by foreign‑government substantial interests or critical‑technology factors.

What is the size and cost of CoreWeave's.answer: CoreWeave’s Magnetar-led loan was a $2.3 billion delayed-draw debt facility announced on August 3, 2023. It also stipulates a first‑priority perfected security interest in substantially all borrower assets, with UCC filings and collateral and guarantee requirements, reflecting the asset‑backed nature of the facility.

search_results.snippet: 9fin explains CoreWeave’s two delayed‑draw term loans co‑led by Magnetar and Blackstone—$2.3bn (2023) and $7.6bn (2024). What emissions reporting and sustainabil.query: What emissions reporting and sustainability disclosures are mandated for CoreWeave in 2025?
What emissions reporting and sustainabil.answer: In 2025, CoreWeave’s binding mandates come primarily from California’s climate disclosure laws (if it does business in California and meets the revenue thresholds). Under SB 261, it must publish a climate-related financial risk report by Jan 1, 2026 (covering 2025), with CARB opening a public docket on Dec 1, 2025 for links. Under SB 253, it must measure 2025 Scope 1–2 GHG emissions for first public disclosure in 2026; Scope 3 begins in 2027. At the federal level, the SEC’s climate rule is stayed and, as of Mar 27, 2025, the SEC ended its defense of the rule, so no SEC-mandated emissions disclosures apply in 2025.

search_results.title: California Corporate GHG Reporting and Climate Risk Disclosure Programs (CARB)

Both laws apply to public and private companies and are being implemented by CARB, which has issued an enforcement notice and draft templates for initial reports due beginning in 2026.

search_results.title: California climate disclosure laws: CARB refines applicability, deadlines, and scope (White & Case)
search_results.snippet: CARB proposed a June 30, 2026 initial deadline for SB 253 Scope 1–2 disclosures covering fiscal 2025 emissions; Scope 3 reporting starts in 2027 for fiscal 2026. For SB 261, companies must publish their first climate-related financial risk report by Jan 1, 2026, with a CARB public docket opening Dec 1, 2025 for posting report links. CARB emphasized ‘good faith’ first-year compliance while rulemaking proceeds.

search_results.title: SEC Votes to End Defense of Climate Disclosure Rules
search_results.snippet: On Mar 27, 2025, the SEC voted to end its defense of the 2024 climate disclosure rules, which had already been stayed pending litigation. As a result, the SEC’s climate-related disclosure rules are not being enforced while the case remains in the Eighth Circuit, meaning no new SEC-mandated emissions disclosures apply in 2025.

What labor regulations affect CoreWeave'.query: What labor regulations affect CoreWeave's rapid hiring and data center operations?
What labor regulations affect CoreWeave'.answer: CoreWeave’s rapid hiring is governed by the Fair Labor Standards Act—requiring overtime pay for non-exempt employees after 40 hours and accurate tracking of hours—and by the DOL’s 2024 independent contractor rule, which uses a six-factor, totality-of-circumstances test to determine employee vs. contractor status. Its data center operations are constrained by OSHA’s electrical safety and lockout/tagout standards (29 CFR 1910.147 and 1910.333), which mandate de-energization, energy-control procedures, training, and PPE during servicing and maintenance. Together, these rules shape staffing models, contractor use, scheduling, and safe maintenance in data centers.

search_results.title: Employee or Independent Contractor Classification Under the Fair Labor Standards Act
search_results.snippet: Final DOL rule effective March 11, 2024 revises FLSA worker classification, returning to a totality-of-circumstances “economic reality” test with six factors (profit/loss, investments, permanence, control, integral nature of work, skill/initiative). It clarifies when workers are employees entitled to wage/overtime protections versus independent contractors—central to staffing and rapid hiring strategies.

search_results.title: Lockout/Tagout - OSHA Fact Sheet
search_results.snippet: OSHA’s control of hazardous energy standard (29 CFR 1910.147) and electrical work practices (1910.333) require de‑energizing circuits and using lockout/tagout, written energy‑control procedures, training, and approved devices and PPE when servicing equipment. Compliance prevents fatalities and injuries—directly impacting data center maintenance and operations.

search_results.title: Overtime - Worker.gov
search_results.snippet: Under the FLSA, covered non‑exempt employees must receive overtime pay of at least 1.5× their regular rate for hours worked over 40 in a seven‑day workweek. Employers must pay for all hours worked, and DOL’s Wage and Hour Division enforces these rights—core requirements when scaling 24/7 data center staffing.

What is CoreWeave's plan if export contr.query: What is CoreWeave's plan if export controls restrict advanced GPUs to certain regions?
What is CoreWeave's plan if export contr.answer: CoreWeave’s stated approach is to comply with export rules while continuing to expand in permitted geographies and to use policy frameworks that enable lawful global access. The company publicly advocates for “strategic” export controls that protect national security yet allow the American AI stack to diffuse abroad, and it is actively building data centers in allied markets (UK, Nordics, Spain). Under the BIS AI Diffusion framework, U.S. AI cloud providers can use UVEU/NVEU authorizations to deploy global data centers while concentrating most compute in Tier‑1 allies—providing a path for CoreWeave to serve demand by placing advanced GPUs where allowed and limiting or avoiding restricted regions.

This signals a plan to expand where rules permit and operate under compliant frameworks rather than exit entire regions.

search_results.snippet: BIS’s AI Diffusion framework allows U.S. AI cloud providers to obtain a Universal Validated End User (UVEU) license to run global data centers if most compute remains in Tier‑1 allies (≥75% in Tier‑1, ≤7% per other country; U.S.-headquartered UVEUs keep ≥50% in the U.S.), or to use country-specific NVEU approvals—enabling service to non‑Tier‑1 markets while concentrating advanced GPUs in permitted regions.

How vulnerable is CoreWeave to hardware.query: How vulnerable is CoreWeave to hardware supply shocks affecting Nvidia or server OEMs?
How vulnerable is CoreWeave to hardware.answer: CoreWeave is highly exposed to Nvidia and server OEM supply shocks. Its S‑1 shows the fleet is entirely Nvidia-based and that new systems are received from a small set of OEM partners (notably Dell and Super Micro), so any disruption in Nvidia’s chip output (e.g., HBM or packaging bottlenecks) or OEM assembly/logistics can delay capacity additions. While partnerships give CoreWeave early access and fast deployments, the supplier concentration and reliance on OEM-delivered racks mean hardware supply shocks would materially constrain growth.

How does CoreWeave plan to reduce intere.query: How does CoreWeave plan to reduce interest expense per revenue dollar in 2025?
How does CoreWeave plan to reduce intere.answer: Management says it will lower interest expense per revenue dollar by reducing its cost of capital and tightly matching debt to long‑term customer contracts. Specifically, CoreWeave is using self‑amortizing, contract‑aligned financing that naturally deleverages, continuing to tap public debt markets post‑IPO to refinance higher‑cost borrowings, and expanding liquidity—steps that CFO Nitin Agrawal says should make interest costs a smaller drag as revenue scales. On the Q2 call, the company guided that interest expense would be partly offset by an increasingly lower cost of capital in the back half of 2025.

search_results.title: CoreWeave First Quarter 2025 Earnings Conference Call (Transcript)

He also described the company’s use of self‑amortizing, contract‑matched financing that naturally deleverages—mechanics designed to reduce financing burden relative to revenue over time.

report:
# CoreWeave, Inc. (Nasdaq: CRWV) — Next-Day Trading Outlook and Investment Research

## 1) Investment Recommendation Summary
- Investment stance: NEUTRAL  
- Rating: HOLD  
- Next market day call: Range-bound with slight upside bias (+0% to +3%), absent macro shocks or unexpected company disclosures  
- Rationale: Strong revenue visibility and improving financing terms are balanced by heavy interest burden, concentration risk, and substantial off–balance sheet commitments.

## 2) Executive Summary
CoreWeave is scaling a purpose-built AI cloud with multi-year, take-or-pay contracts that provide unusual visibility and backlog depth. The OpenAI framework and other contracted revenues strengthen utilization and underpin FY25 guidance. At the same time, the capital structure remains a key overhang: interest expense is elevated with thin coverage, GAAP profitability timing remains uncertain, and lease obligations are large and growing. We expect shares to be stable to modestly higher next session as investors weigh durable backlog and improving cost of capital against financing risk and concentration.

Key positives:
- Large, front-loaded backlog with strong conversion over the next two years, and FY25 revenue raised to $5.15–$5.35B [11][18].
- Contracts are predominantly multi-year, take-or-pay; OpenAI adds multi-billion commitments with defined termination mechanics [2][1][3].
- Financing costs trending down on new draws (DDTL 2.0 repriced) and terming-out debt to 2030 [23][17][26].

Key watch-outs:
- Interest expense and coverage remain weak; GAAP net losses persist despite positive operating income [5][6][8][7].
- Customer concentration is high; although expected to moderate, it is a near-term risk factor [15][9][4].
- Heavy lease commitments and credit covenants may constrain flexibility in a capex-intensive buildout [14][2].

Bottom line: Risk/reward is balanced near term; maintain HOLD.

## 3) Company Overview
CoreWeave operates a specialized AI cloud focused on GPU-accelerated compute, storage, networking, and managed services for AI training, inference, VFX/rendering, and other high-performance workloads. Segments include GPU/CPU Compute, AI Object Storage, Networking, and Managed Services. FY2024 revenue was $1.9B with a net loss of $863M (market cap ~$51.8B as of 2025-11-10). The company differentiates versus hyperscalers through workload-specific performance, rapid adoption of NVIDIA’s latest GPUs, and take-or-pay contracts that provide revenue visibility.

## 4) Key Findings by Category

### Revenue, Backlog, and Guidance
- FY2025 guidance raised post-Q2: $5.15–$5.35B (from $4.9–$5.1B), reflecting robust demand [18].  
- Backlog: $30.1B as of Q2’25 (includes RPO and additional contracted amounts subject to delivery/availability) [5]; $25.9B at Q1 [12].  
- RPO timing: $14.7B unsatisfied RPO at Q1’25; 58% expected to be recognized over the next 24 months, 40% in months 25–48, remainder in months 49–72 [11].  
- Revenue mix: “Vast majority” from multi-year, committed (take-or-pay) contracts, implying modest usage-based exposure in FY25 [19][20].

Analyst view: The conversion profile (58% in 24 months) supports near-term growth and underpins FY25 guidance; the backlog composition is a key buffer against volatility.

### Contract Structure and OpenAI
- OpenAI MSA/order forms: The company references up to ~$11.55B tied to the OpenAI framework in the prospectus, and a subsequent order form (Sept. 2025) where OpenAI committed up to ~$6.5B through May 31, 2031, subject to termination provisions and delivery/availability [2][1].  
- Termination mechanics: MSA allows termination for cause after cure periods; during any Termination Period, services continue and are payable only for services performed. If CoreWeave terminates for nonpayment, it must continue services during the Termination Period and may then transfer/sell reserved servers with proceeds credited against amounts owed [3].  
- Accounting: RPO disclosure excluded amounts from the OpenAI Commercial Agreement as of Q1’25 while accounting evaluation continued; deferred revenue included $450M from OpenAI at March 31, 2025 [11].  
- Management commentary: Backlog cited at $30.1B; a $4B OpenAI expansion over an $11.9B MSA was discussed; a $2.6B loan completed financing for the OpenAI contract (no specific FY25 revenue breakout) [8][11].

Analyst view: Contractual structure (take-or-pay, termination mechanics, collateralization) enhances visibility and mitigates counterparty risk. The exclusion of OpenAI balances from RPO at Q1 suggests conservatism in reported backlog metrics [11].

### Customer Concentration and Diversification
- Concentration: “Customer A” accounted for 72% of revenue in Q1’25 [15]. In Q2’25, only one customer exceeded 10% [4].  
- Mitigation: S-1/A indicates Microsoft was the largest customer in 2023–2024 but is expected to account for under half of future committed contract revenue when combining 2024 RPO ($15.1B) with the newly signed OpenAI MSA [9].  

Analyst view: Concentration remains a key risk, albeit expected to moderate as OpenAI and other customers scale.

### Profitability and Margins
- Q2’25 results: Revenue $1.213B; GAAP operating income $19.2M; GAAP net loss $290.5M; adjusted operating income $199.8M [7][5].  
- Interest burden: Q2’25 interest expense, net was $267.0M; LTM interest coverage ~0.32x per third-party aggregator, underscoring limited coverage [5][6].  
- Q3 outlook (from Q2 call): Adjusted operating income $160–$190M vs. guided interest expense $350–$390M, implying continued GAAP pressure [8].  
- Margins: Adjusted EBITDA margin ~62% in Q2’25 [29]. External analysis highlights reported ~74% GAAP gross margin in Q2 and questions the comparability due to cost classification, with no training vs. inference margin breakout disclosed [30][29].  
- NDR: The company has not disclosed a 2025 net dollar retention figure [4].

Analyst view: Unit economics look strong on an adjusted basis, but high interest expense is the swing factor for GAAP profitability. Margin disclosure lacks granularity, a point of investor debate.

### Balance Sheet, Liquidity, and Cost of Capital
- Debt stack improvements:
  - $2.0B senior notes due 2030 at 9.25% (proceeds used to term debt and for general corporate purposes) [17].  
  - Revolver upsized to $1.5B; maturity extended to May 2, 2028, with a springing maturity to Dec 30, 2026 under certain conditions [16][26].  
  - DDTL 2.0 repriced: new draws at SOFR + 4.25% or base + 3.25% (0% floor), down from SOFR + 6–13% depending on counterparty credit (prior grid) [23].  
  - Magnetar-led facility $2.3B; draws secured by contracted revenues first, then GPU collateral, with parent guarantee support [24][25].  
- OEM financing: $1.728B outstanding as of Q2’25; effective interest rates 9–10%; maturities 2026–2028 [13].  
- Fitch view: Capital intensity peaks in 2025; deleveraging expected as EBITDA outgrows new debt needs—implying free cash flow inflection over the medium term rather than near-term [22].

Analyst view: Pricing on new credit has improved and maturities extended, but aggregate interest remains high. Liquidity is ample; covenants and commitments will require disciplined execution.

### Capital Commitments, Leases, and Covenants
- Leases: $3.45B PV of operating lease liabilities at Q2’25; $34.0B additional undiscounted lease payments for leases not yet commenced; potential fixed lease payments up to $0.9B over 13 years subject to regulatory approvals [14].  
- Covenants: Debt instruments contain restrictive covenants limiting additional debt/liens, investments/acquisitions, asset sales, restricted payments, and mergers, potentially constraining capex and M&A unless within baskets or with consent [2].

Analyst view: The scale of contractual lease commitments is substantial and increases operational leverage to demand. Covenants necessitate prudent capital allocation.

### Operations and Capacity; Supply Chain Risk
- Power/capacity: ~470 MW active and 2.2 GW total contracted power at Q2; company guided to >900 MW active by year-end 2025; no explicit 2026 targets disclosed [32].  
- GPU supply/utilization backstop: NVIDIA agreed to purchase residual, unsold CoreWeave capacity up to $6.3B through April 2032—supporting utilization and supply assurance [33].

Analyst view: Capacity ramp supports revenue scale, while the NVIDIA backstop materially reduces utilization risk in a volatile supply environment.

### Geographic Mix
- Revenue remains overwhelmingly U.S.-based in 1H’25; UK and “All Other Countries” (largely Europe) represent a small share [27][28].

### M&A Update
- Core Scientific deal terminated on Oct 30, 2025 after stockholder non-approval, removing near-term integration risk [10].

### Credit Risk and Receivables Management
- As of Q1’25: Accounts receivable, net were $1.06B; deferred revenue $3.61B, reflecting sizable prepayments and billings that partially offset receivable risk. The company highlights concentration in accounts receivable [21].

## 5) Investment Thesis

### Bull Case
- Dense backlog with front-loaded conversion: 58% of $14.7B RPO recognized within 24 months; FY25 guidance was raised on strong demand [11][18].  
- Contract durability: Multi-year, take-or-pay constructs and OpenAI commitments with defined termination mechanics, plus NVIDIA backstop reduce utilization and counterparty risks [2][1][3][33].  
- Improving cost of capital: Revolver upsized, DDTL repriced down, 2030 notes issued—collectively lengthening duration and lowering cost on incremental draws [26][23][17].  
- Operating leverage: Adjusted EBITDA margins in the low-60% range, with management framework to sustain ~60%+ into 2026 as mix shifts to higher-margin services [29][31].

### Bear Case
- Financing drag: Interest expense and coverage are the principal overhang; Q2 interest of ~$267M and guided Q3 interest $350–$390M overwhelm adjusted operating profits [5][8].  
- Concentration: A single customer accounted for 72% of Q1’25 revenue; although expected to decline, it remains a near-term risk [15][9].  
- Commitments and covenants: $34B of leases not yet commenced and restrictive covenants elevate operational leverage and reduce financial flexibility in a capital-intensive buildout [14][2].  
- Disclosure quality: No NDR and limited per-workload margin transparency; external scrutiny of GAAP gross margin comparability persists [4][30].

## 6) Key Risks
- Counterparty/Concentration risk: Revenue and receivables concentration in a few hyperscale customers; mitigation via take-or-pay terms and NVIDIA backstop, but concentration remains elevated [15][2][33].  
- Interest rate and refinancing risk: While recent financings reduce cost on new draws, aggregate interest remains high and profitability timeline uncertain; a prolonged high-rate environment would pressure equity value [5][6][23][17].  
- Execution risk on capacity ramp: Meeting power and infrastructure milestones while controlling unit costs and ensuring availability/delivery obligations [32].  
- Covenant and liquidity management: Restrictive covenants and large lease commitments could constrain strategic optionality and increase sensitivity to demand shocks [2][14].  
- Accounting/Disclosure risk: RPO exclusions (OpenAI) and lack of NDR/margin granularity may contribute to valuation uncertainty [11][4][30].

## 7) Conclusion and Outlook

Rating: HOLD  
Stance: NEUTRAL

Next-day trading outlook: We expect CRWV to trade sideways to modestly higher (+0% to +3%) on the next market day. Supportive factors include raised FY25 guidance, substantial backlog with front-loaded conversion, improved financing terms for incremental borrowing, and the NVIDIA utilization backstop [18][11][26][23][33]. Offsetting headwinds are the heavy interest burden with weak coverage, concentration risk, and sizable lease/capex commitments [5][6][15][14]. 

Medium-term view: If CoreWeave sustains contract conversion and continues to lower its effective cost of capital while diversifying its customer mix, risk/reward could skew more positive as interest coverage improves. Conversely, any disruption to customer ramp, delivery/availability constraints, or financing conditions would challenge the path to GAAP profitability and free cash flow inflection [8][22][2]. 

Catalysts to watch:
- Q3 results and 2026 margin/capacity updates [8][31][32].  
- Additional contract wins/expansions or disclosures on OpenAI revenue recognition timing [11][8].  
- Further balance sheet actions (debt repricing, OEM financing cadence) and covenant headroom [13][23][17][2].  

Given the balanced setup, we remain NEUTRAL with a HOLD rating pending clearer visibility on interest coverage improvement and customer concentration normalization.
